description: Probably from Middle English vilein, from Old French vilein (modern French vilain), in turn from Late Latin villanus, meaning serf or peasant, someone who is bound to the soil of a Latin villa, which is to say, worked on the equivalent of a plantation in late Antiquity, in Italy or Gaul. Doublet of villein.

entries.meaning: An extremely depraved person, or one capable or guilty of great crimes.
In fiction, a character who has the role of being bad, especially antagonizing the hero.
(poker) Any opponent player, especially a hypothetical player for example and didactic purposes. Compare: hero (“the current player”).
examples: Let's discuss how to play if you are the chip leader (that is, if you have more chips than all the villains).

entries.meaning: Archaic form of villein (“feudal tenant, peasant, serf”).

verbs.description: villain (third-person singular simple present villains, present participle villaining, simple past and past participle villained)

entries.meaning: (obsolete, transitive) To debase; to degrade[16th century].
